question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
There exist constants $p$ and $q$ so that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ the vectors $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c},$ $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c},$ and $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c}$ are always collinear.  Enter the ordered pair $(p,q).$
inference:
Let $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c},$ $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c},$ and $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c}$ be collinear.  This means that one of the vectors is a scalar multiple of another.  Thus there exists a scalar $k$ such that
\begin{align*} 2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c} &= k (\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c}) \\ &= k \mathbf{a} - 2k \mathbf{b} + 3k \mathbf{c}. \end{align*}Equating coefficients, we obtain the system of equations
\begin{align*} 2 &= k, \\ 3 &= -2k, \\ -4 &= 3k, \\ 0 &= p, \\ 0 &= q. \end{align*}From $2 = k$, we get $3 = -2k = -4,$ which is impossible.  Therefore,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c} &= k (2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) \\ &= 2k \mathbf{a} + 3k \mathbf{b} - 4k \mathbf{c}. \end{align*}Equating coefficients, we obtain the system of equations
\begin{align*} 1 &= 2k, \\ -2 &= 3k, \\ 3 &= -4k. \end{align*}From $1 = 2k$, we get $k = \frac{1}{2}.$  Then $-2 = 3k$, so $k = -\frac{2}{3}$.  And $3 = -4k$, so $k = -\frac{3}{4}$.  These are contradictory.
Instead, we must have
\begin{align*} p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c} &= m (\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c}) + n (2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) \\ &= (m + 2n) \mathbf{a} + (-2m + 3n) \mathbf{b} + (3m - 4n) \mathbf{c}. \end{align*}We require $m + 2n = 0,$ $-2m + 3n = p,$ and $3m - 4n = q.$  From $m = -2n,$ we have
\begin{align*} p &= -2m + 3n = -2(-2n) + 3n = 4n + 3n = 7n, \\ q &= 3m - 4n = 3(-2n) - 4n = -6n - 4n = -10n. \end{align*}Let $n = 1.$  Then $p = 7$ and $q = -10.$  Thus $(p, q) = (7, -10).$

Final Answer: $\boxed{(7,-10)}$
ground_truth:
The line through $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c}$ and $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}$ can be parameterized by
\begin{align*}
&\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c} + t((2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) - (\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c})) \\
&= (1 + t) \mathbf{a} + (-2 + 5t) \mathbf{b} + (3 - 7t) \mathbf{c}.
\end{align*}To get an expression of the form $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c},$ we want the coefficient of $\mathbf{a}$ to be 0.  Thus, we take $t = -1,$ which gives us $-7 \mathbf{b} + 10 \mathbf{c}.$  Hence, $(p,q) = \boxed{(-7,10)}.$

question:

\begin{align*} 2 &= k, \\ 3 &= -2k, \\ -4 &= 3k, \\ 0 &= p, \\ 0 &= q. \end{align*}From $2 = k$, we get $3 = -2k = -4,$ which is impossible.  Therefore,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c} &= k (2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) \\ &= 2k \mathbf{a} + 3k \mathbf{b} - 4k \mathbf{c}. \end{align*}Equating coefficients, we obtain the system of equations

Instead, we must have
\begin{align*} p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c} &= m (\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c}) + n (2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) \\ &= (m + 2n) \mathbf{a} + (-2m + 3n) \mathbf{b} + (3m - 4n) \mathbf{c}. \end{align*}We require $m + 2n = 0,$ $-2m + 3n = p,$ and $3m - 4n = q.$  From $m = -2n,$ we have
\begin{align*} p &= -2m + 3n = -2(-2n) + 3n = 4n + 3n = 7n, \\ q &= 3m - 4n = 3(-2n) - 4n = -6n - 4n = -10n. \end{align*}Let $n = 1.$  Then $p = 7$ and $q = -10.$  Thus $(p, q) = (7, -10).$

Final Answer: $\boxed{(7,-10)}$

inference:
Let $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c},$ $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c},$ and $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c}$ be collinear.  This means there exist scalars $m$ and $n$ such that
\begin{align*} p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c} &= m (\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c}) + n (2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) \\ &= (m + 2n) \mathbf{a} + (-2m + 3n) \mathbf{b} + (3m - 4n) \mathbf{c}. \end{align*}Comparing coefficients, we require
\begin{align*} m + 2n &= 0, \\ -2m + 3n &= p, \\ 3m - 4n &= q. \end{align*}From $m + 2n = 0,$ $m = -2n.$  Substituting into $-2m + 3n = p,$ we get $4n + 3n = 7n = p.$  Substituting into $3m - 4n = q,$ we get $-6n - 4n = -10n = q.$  Thus, $p = 7n$ and $q = -10n.$  If $n = 1,$ then $p = 7$ and $q = -10.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{(7,-10)}$

The line through $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c}$ and $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}$ can be parameterized by
\begin{align*}
&\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c} + t((2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) - (\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c})) \\
&= (1 + t) \mathbf{a} + (-2 + 5t) \mathbf{b} + (3 - 7t) \mathbf{c}.
\end{align*}To get an expression of the form $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c},$ we want the coefficient of $\mathbf{a}$ to be 0.  Thus, we take $t = -1,$ which gives us $-7 \mathbf{b} + 10 \mathbf{c}.$  Hence, $(p,q) = \boxed{(-7,10)}.$
